contentrichtext.text: {{more footnotes|date=March 2012}} [[File:Yank, The Army Weekly, April 13, 1945, Cover art of Rifle Company Medic.jpg|thumb|Yank, The Army Weekly, April 13, 1945, Cover art of Rifle Company Medic]] [[File:Jane Randolph in Yank magazine.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Jane Randolph]] for the debut June 17, 1942 issue.]] '''''Yank, the Army Weekly''''' was a weekly magazine published by the [[United States military]] during [[World War II]]. The idea for the magazine came from [[Egbert White]], who had worked on [[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]] during World War I. He proposed the idea to the Army in early 1942, and accepted a commission as Lieutenant Colonel. White was the overall commander, Major [[Franklin S. Forsberg]] was the business manager and Major [[Hartzell Spence]] was the first editor.<ref>{{cite book |last= McGurn|first= Barrett |title= Yank the Army Weekly: Reporting the Greatest Generation|publisher= Fulcrum Publishing |year= 2004 |isbn= 1-55591-296-6}} page 65</ref> White was removed from the Yank staff because of disagreements about articles which had appeared.<ref>{{cite journal |last=White |first=Egbert|journal=Journal of Educational Sociology|volume=19|number=4|title=A Free Press in a Citizen's Army |pages=236â€“248 |jstor=2263264}}</ref> Soon afterward, Spence was also assigned to other duties and Joe McCarthy became the editor.<ref>McGurn p 87-89</ref> The first issue was published with the cover date of June 17, 1942.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} The magazine was written by [[enlisted rank]] soldiers only and was made available to the soldiers, sailors, and airmen serving overseas. It was published at facilities around the world—British, Mediterranean, Continental, and Western Pacific—for a total of 21 editions in 17 countries. ''Yank'' was the most widely read magazine in the history of the U.S. military, achieving a worldwide circulation of more than 2.6 million. Each issue was priced from five cents to 10 cents because it was felt that if soldiers paid, they would have a higher regard for the publication. Each issue was edited in [[New York City]] and then shipped for printing around the world where staff editors added local stories. The last issue was published in December 1945. [[Scott Corbett]] (later known as a writer of novels for children) served as the last editor. Sketch artists such as Robert Greenhalgh and Howard Brodie worked on the magazine, which also featured the "[[G.I. Joe (comics)|G.I. Joe]]" cartoons by [[Dave Breger]] and the ''[[Sad Sack]]'' cartoons by [[George Baker (cartoonist)|Sgt. George Baker]]. Artist and author [[Jack Coggins]] spent over two years with ''Yank'', first in New York, then in London, producing illustrations and articles in more than 24 issues.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} [[John Bushemi]] was a photographer, who photographed the [[Pacific War]] and provided covers for ''Yank''.<ref name="WDL">{{cite web |url = http://www.wdl.org/en/item/453/ |title = Operations Against the Japanese on Arundel and Sagekarsa Islands |website = [[World Digital Library]] |date = 1943 |accessdate = 2013-06-02 }}</ref> One of the most popular "morale boosters" for the men in the armed forces was the inclusion of a [[pin-up girl]] in each issue who was usually clad either in a bathing suit or some form of seductive attire. The pin-up girls included stage and screen stars. ==In popular culture== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2013}} ''Yank'' figures in the plot of ''Yank! A WWII Love Story'', a musical by Joseph and David Zellnik. The musical had its off-Broadway debut at the [[York Theatre]] in New York in February 2010 with a cast including [[Bobby Steggert]], Ivan Herndez, Nancy Anderson and Jeffry Denman. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Yank, the Army Weekly covers}} * {{cite web | url = http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/University_Library/libs/hay/focus/focus2/focus2.html | title = The Art of Yank Magazine: The World War Two Drawings of Robert Greenhalgh | publisher = Special Collections, [[Brown University Library]] | accessdate = February 13, 2013}} * {{cite web | url = http://americanhistory.si.edu/militaryhistory/collection/object.asp?ID=827 | title = ''Yank'' | publisher = (Cover, February 20, 1944 issue, British edition) [[National Museum of American History]] | accessdate = February 13, 2013}} * {{cite web | url = http://www.wartimepress.com/archives.asp?TID=Yank%20Magazine%20-%20All%20Editions&MID=Army&q=41&FID=36 | title = Army: ''Yank'' Magazine - All Editions | publisher= (Archive of select issues) Wartime Press | accessdate = February 13, 2013}} [[Category:Defunct magazines of the United States]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1942]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1945]] [[Category:World War II media]] [[Category:United States Army publications]] [[Category:World Digital Library related]]
